facts.text: Respondent claimed to be a voter of the Ajmer Municipality.
By order dated March 12, 1953, the Ajmer Municipal Committee was suspended till September 11, 1955.

Chief Commissioner, Ajmer (appellant) framed Ajmer State Municipalities Election Rules, 1955 under s.43 of Ajmer-Merwara Municipalities Regulation, 1925, published in Government Gazette dated August 4, 1955.
On August 8, 1955, Chief Commissioner notified election programme and authenticated and published electoral roll, which had been corrected and altered by Sub-Divisional Officer prior thereto.
Respondent's name in electoral roll incorrectly described: father's name as Ratan Lal instead of Chitar Mal.
On August 10, 1955, respondent applied for correction of father's name in Parliamentary Electoral Roll.
On August 16, 1955, respondent filed nomination paper.
On August 17, 1955, Returning Officer rejected respondent's nomination stating he was not one of the electors according to the roll.
On August 18, 1955, Electoral Registration Officer rejected respondent's application for rectification on ground that municipal roll finally published on August 8, 1955.

On August 26, 1955, respondent filed Civil Writ Petition No. 108 of 1955 in Judicial Commissioner's Court, Ajmer against appellant and District Magistrate for mandamus to reconstitute Committee under s.81 and restrain elections on September 9, 1955.

Judicial Commissioner, by judgment dated September 5, 1955, upheld respondent's contention on reconstitution (already done by appellant), held Rule 7 not in consonance with/contradicting s.30(2), in excess of rule-making power; directed District Magistrate to refrain from holding elections on September 9, 1955.
Judicial Commissioner refused certificate under Art.133(1)(c) as date September 9, 1955 had passed.
Supreme Court granted special leave under Art.136.
Appeal heard ex parte as respondent did not appear.
Appellant had reconstituted Ajmer Municipal Committee by notification under s.81 before Judicial Commissioner's judgment.
Date of proposed elections, September 9, 1955, had passed by time of Supreme Court hearing.

legal_issues.text: Whether Rule 7 of Ajmer State Municipalities Election Rules, 1955 is not in consonance with and contradicts s.30 sub-s.(2) of Ajmer-Merwara Municipalities Regulation, 1925 and is in excess of rule-making power conferred by s.43.

petitioner_arguments.text: Pronouncement of Judicial Commissioner that Rule 7 is invalid is a stumbling block for holding future elections on basis of electoral roll authenticated August 8, 1955; requires setting aside to avoid need for new roll and expenses.

court_reasoning.text: To be elector under s.30(2), person must: (1) be entitled under Representation of the People Act, 1950 to be registered in Parliamentary roll if constituency co-extensive with Municipality; (2) name registered in Parliamentary roll comprising Municipality.
court_reasoning.key_observation: First condition requires scrutiny of qualifications; second apparent from roll.

court_reasoning.text: Necessary to provide for revision of electoral rolls, adjudication of claims and objections under s.43(c); Rules 7 and 9 treat final printed Parliamentary roll as municipal roll but omit provisions for scrutiny, revision, claims, objections.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rules defective as they do not ensure proper electoral rolls; elections on imperfect rolls invalid.

court_reasoning.text: Expression 'final printed roll' does not incorporate procedures of Representation of the People Act, 1950 into Regulation or Rules.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rules 7 and 9 either inconsistent with s.30(2) or defective for failing to provide procedure.

court_reasoning.text: Electoral roll authenticated August 8, 1955 not prepared in accordance with law; cannot form basis for valid elections.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No need to decide if section prevails over rules; roll non-conforming.

holdings.text: Electoral roll of Ajmer Municipality authenticated and published August 8, 1955 not in conformity with s.30(2) and relevant provisions; cannot form basis of valid elections.

statutes_cited.name: Ajmer-Merwara Municipalities Regulation, 1925 (VI of 1925)
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs electors, rule-making for electoral rolls, reconstitution of Committee; Rule 7 held defective/inconsistent with s.30(2)

statutes_cited.name: Representation of the People Act, 1950 (XLIII of 1950)
statutes_cited.relevance: Qualifications for registration in Parliamentary electoral roll adopted as basis for municipal electors under s.30(2)

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate refused under Art.133; special leave granted under Art.136

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed as without substance; upheld invalidity of electoral roll and Rules 7/9 for lacking provisions on revision, claims, objections; no valid elections possible on that roll.

key_quotes.text: It is of the essence of these elections that proper electoral rolls should be maintained and in order that a proper electoral roll should be maintained it is necessary that after the preparation of the electoral roll opportunity should be given to the parties concerned to scrutinize whether the persons enrolled as electors possessed the requisite qualifications.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning on necessity of scrutiny and revision for valid electoral rolls

key_quotes.text: Under the circumstances we see no substance in the appeal and dismiss the same.
key_quotes.speaker: court
